'''Mighty Mo Rodgers''' (born July 24, 1942)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sonicbids.com/band/mightymorodgers4/about/ |title=About Mighty Mo Rodgers |publisher=Sonicbids.com |date=July 24, 1942 |accessdate=March 13, 2014}}</ref> is an American [[electric blues]] musician, singer, songwriter, and record producer, who has released six albums to date.<ref name="AMG"/> He has been influenced by the work of [[Aretha Franklin]], [[Bobby Bland]], [[Eddie Boyd]], [[Jimmy Reed]], [[Otis Redding]], [[Sam & Dave]], and [[Willie Dixon]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/mighty-mo-rodgers-mn0000407489/related |title=Mighty Mo Rodgers | Similar Artists, Influenced By, Followers |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=March 13, 2014}}</ref>

[[Bonnie Riatt]] noted that "Mo Rodgers' music is a breath of fresh air in the blues/R&B world. He combines sly social commentary with a great funky sound...I love his voice. He's a welcome original."<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.bignoisenow.com/mightymorodgers.html |title=Mighty Mo Rodgers Official Website |publisher=Bignoisenow.com |date= |accessdate=March 13, 2014}}</ref>

==Biography==
'''Maurice Rodgers''' was born in [[East Chicago, Indiana]], United States,<ref name="AMG"/>

He studied [[classical music|classical]] piano, but was more influenced by witnessing the blues acts that performed at his father's [[nightclub]]. In the mid 1960s, the music produced by the American [[record label]], [[Stax Records|Stax]], also affected his musical ambitions. In high school, Rodgers formed his first band known as the Rocketeers. After entering [[Indiana State College]], he [[frontman|fronted]] the Maurice Rodgers Combo. His love of playing keyboards led Rodgers to leave college and relocate to Los Angeles, California, becoming a full-time musician.<ref name="AMG"/>

He played the [[Farfisa]] [[electric organ]] on [[Brenton Wood]]'s 1967 hit, "[[Gimme Little Sign]]".<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Rodgers">{{cite web|url=http://www.mightymorodgers.com/bio.html |title=Mighty Mo Rodgers Bio Page |publisher=Mightymorodgers.com |date= |accessdate=March 13, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soulbluesmusic.com/mightymorodgers.htm |title=Mighty Mo Rodgers |publisher=Soulbluesmusic.com |date= |accessdate=March 13, 2014}}</ref>

In 1973, Rodgers co-produced the album ''[[Sonny & Brownie]]'' ([[A&M Records]]) by [[Sonny Terry]] and [[Brownie McGhee]].<ref name="Rodgers"/> He also played keyboards on the album's cut.<ref name="AMG"/> Following a spell as a [[session musician]], Rodgers moved into song writing where he penned songs for both [[Motown]] and [[Chappell & Co.]] He also worked as a record producer before returning to education and obtaining a [[Bachelor of Philosophy|philosophy degree]] from [[California State University, Northridge]].<ref name="blues1">{{cite web|last=Limnios |first=Michalis |url=http://blues.gr/profiles/blogs/mighty-mo-rodgers-a-blues-poet-philosopher-socrates-laid-down |title=Mighty Mo Rodgers, a blues poet philosopher: Socrates laid down some real good Blues "know thyself" |publisher=Blues.Gr |date=July 27, 2012 |accessdate=March 13, 2014}}</ref> His first solo album was released in 1999 by [[Blue Thumb Records]]. ''Blues Is My Wailin' Wall'' included Rodgers' philosophical views on mankind in several of the songs lyrics.<ref name="AMG"/>

In 2000, Rodgers performed at the [[Notodden Blues Festival]].  His European excursions have included concerts at the [[New Morning (club)|New Morning]] [[nightclub]] in Paris. In 2001, Rodgers performed on the album ''Memphis'' recorded by [[Jean-Jacques Milteau]], which also included contributions from [[Little Milton]] and [[Mighty Sam McClain]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/memphis-mw0000031055/credits |title=Memphis – Jean-Jacques Milteau | Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=March 13, 2014}}</ref> His own recordings continued with ''Red, White & Blues'' (2002), ''Black Paris Blues'' a [[live album]] issued in 2004, and ''Redneck Blues'' (2007). His most recent release was ''Cadillac Jack'' in 2012.<ref name="allmusic1">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/mighty-mo-rodgers-mn0000407489/discography |title=Mighty Mo Rodgers | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=March 13, 2014}}</ref>

Rodgers is due to appear at the 22nd [[Salmon Arm Roots and Blues Festival]] in August 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rootsandblues.ca/mighty-mo-rodgers/ |title=Mighty Mo Rodgers : Salmon Arm Roots and Blues Festival / Music / Canadian / International / World / Family Event |publisher=Rootsandblues.ca |date=April 4, 2013 |accessdate=March 13, 2014}}</ref>

==Awards==
*[[Blues Music Award|W.C. Handy Award]] nomination (1999) for ''Blues Is My Wailin' Wall''
*Chic De L' Annee (1999) (France) as Blues Album of the Year for ''Blues Is My Wailin' Wall''
*Contemporary Blues Album of the Year (2002) by ''[[Living Blues]]'' for ''Red, White & Blues''
*[[Académie Charles Cros]] ([[Grand Prix du Disque]]) (2002) for ''Red, White & Blues''
*Trophees France Blues (2001) and (2002) International Artist
*Trophees France Blues (2003) International Songwriter
*Chic De L'Annee (2007) Blues Album of the Year for ''Redneck Blues''<ref name="Rodgers"/>
